response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "This Act shall be known and may be cited as the Judiciary Appropriations Act of 2025. [CHUNK_1] This bill appropriates funds for the Judiciary for the fiscal biennium beginning 7/1/2025, and ending 6/30/2027. [CHUNK_36] The measure appropriates or authorizes sums from specified funding sources to accomplish the purposes and programs designated for the judiciary. [CHUNK_5]",
  "appropriations": "The bill appropriates funds to the judiciary for the fiscal biennium beginning July 1, 2025, and ending June 30, 2027. [CHUNK_5] This includes operating funds for various judicial circuits and programs, such as JUD101 - Courts of Appeal and JUD310 - First Circuit. [CHUNK_7] It also appropriates $9,900,000 (HB400_.HTM.txt) in general obligation bond funds for capital investment projects. [CHUNK_11, NUMBER_0]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The appropriations are specified for various Program IDs within the judicial system for each year of the fiscal biennium. [CHUNK_4] The total expenditures and the number of permanent and temporary positions established in each fiscal year shall not exceed the sums and the position ceilings indicated for each year, except as provided in this Act. [CHUNK_6] The methodology involves appropriating or authorizing sums from specified sources of funding for designated programs. [CHUNK_5]",
  "agency_impact": "The Judiciary is appropriated funds for its operations and capital improvement projects for the fiscal biennium 2025-2027. [CHUNK_5] The chief justice may transfer sufficient funds and positions between programs for operating purposes. [CHUNK_11] The judiciary may also delegate the planning, acquisition of land, design, construction, and equipment of any capital improvement project to other state or county agencies when it is determined to be advantageous. [CHUNK_24]",
  "economic_impact": "The appropriated funds support the operations of the state's judicial system. [CHUNK_6] Capital improvement projects, including plans and design for a new judiciary complex in South Kohala and upgrades to facilities statewide, are expected to generate economic activity through construction and procurement. [CHUNK_18, CHUNK_20] The total funding for capital projects is $9,900,000 (HB400_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_15, NUMBER_0]",
  "policy_impact": "This Act serves as the judiciary's budget for the 2025-2027 fiscal biennium. [CHUNK_5] It grants the chief justice authority to transfer funds between programs, enter into undertakings with federal or private entities for additional funding, and manage capital improvement projects. [CHUNK_11, CHUNK_14, CHUNK_28] The Act also allows for supplemental allotments for capital projects from the judiciary project adjustment fund. [CHUNK_26]",
  "revenue_sources": "The means of financing for the appropriations include General funds (A), Special funds (B), General obligation bond funds (C), and Revolving funds (W). [CHUNK_3] The capital improvement projects are funded by $9,900,000 (HB400_.HTM.txt) from General obligation bond funds. [CHUNK_11, NUMBER_0] The chief justice may also secure federal funds or funds from private organizations. [CHUNK_13]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "This bill provides appropriations for the fiscal biennium beginning July 1, 2025, and ending June 30, 2027. [CHUNK_5] For fiscal year 2025-2026, operating appropriations include $9,592,659 (A) for the Courts of Appeal and $98,130,866 (A) for the First Circuit. [CHUNK_7] For fiscal year 2026-2027, these appropriations are $9,657,093 (A) and $98,298,808 (A) respectively. [CHUNK_7] The Administration program (JUD601) is appropriated $41,193,756 (A) and $8,241,219 (B) for FY 2026, and $41,042,866 (A) and $8,241,219 (B) for FY 2027. [CHUNK_10] A one-time capital investment appropriation of $9,900,000 (HB400_.HTM.txt) from general obligation bond funds is made for FY 2026. [CHUNK_11, NUMBER_0] These operating costs are recurring and would likely continue in subsequent biennia to maintain judiciary functions. [CHUNK_6] The bill establishes position ceilings for permanent and temporary employees for the two-year period. [CHUNK_6] Capital improvement appropriations that are unencumbered as of June 30, 2028, will lapse. [CHUNK_23] No fiscal projections beyond June 30, 2027 are provided in the act. [CHUNK_6]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The bill primarily appropriates funds and does not focus on revenue generation. [CHUNK_5] It authorizes expenditures from various fund types, including special and revolving funds. [CHUNK_3] The bill allows the chief justice to secure federal funds or funds from private organizations to be expended in connection with authorized programs. [CHUNK_13]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The bill appropriates $9,900,000 (HB400_.HTM.txt) in Part II for capital improvement projects. [CHUNK_15, NUMBER_0] These projects include $4,000,000 for plans and design for a new Judiciary Complex in South Kohala, $900,000 for A/C systems replacement at Puâ€˜uhonua Kaulike, and $5,000,000 for lump sum CIP for judiciary facilities statewide. [CHUNK_18, CHUNK_19, CHUNK_20] These funds are designated for plans, design, construction, and equipment. [CHUNK_20]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "While this bill only covers the 2025-2027 biennium, the operating costs for the judiciary are ongoing and will require continued appropriations in future fiscal periods. [CHUNK_5] The general obligation bonds issued to finance the $9,900,000 (HB400_.HTM.txt) in capital projects will require debt service payments, representing a long-term fiscal obligation for the state. [CHUNK_21, NUMBER_1] All appropriations for capital improvement projects unencumbered as of June 30, 2028, shall lapse as of that date. [CHUNK_23]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "Not applicable as no previous fiscal note was provided.",
  "fte_positions": "The bill establishes a \"Position ceiling,\" which is the maximum number of permanent or temporary positions authorized for a particular program. [CHUNK_3] For the First Circuit (JUD310), the position ceiling for each year of the biennium is 1,115.50 permanent and 57.58 temporary positions. [CHUNK_7] For Administration (JUD601), the ceilings are 234.50 permanent and 8.48 temporary positions from general funds, with an additional 1.00 permanent and 9.00 temporary positions from other funds. [CHUNK_10]",
  "appropriations_changes": "Not applicable as no previous version of the bill was provided.",
  "funding_sources_changes": "Not applicable as no previous version of the bill was provided.",
  "department_impact": "The bill appropriates funds directly to the judiciary for the purposes and programs designated. [CHUNK_5] No changes in departmental responsibility for expending appropriations are mentioned. [CHUNK_5]",
  "reports_required": "If any manifest clerical, typographical, or other mechanical error is found in this Act, the chief justice may correct the error. [CHUNK_34] All changes made pursuant to this section shall be reported to the legislature at its next regular session. [CHUNK_35]",
  "pilot_program": "This bill does not establish a pilot program. [CHUNK_0]",
  "sunset_date": "The bill does not contain a sunset clause for the entire act. [CHUNK_35] However, all appropriations made for fiscal year 2025-2026 and fiscal year 2026-2027 that are unencumbered as of June 30, 2028, shall lapse as of that date. [CHUNK_23]",
  "effective_date": "This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025. [CHUNK_35]"
}

chunk_details.chunk_text: HB400 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 400 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 STATE OF HAWAII A BILL FOR AN ACT relating to the judiciary . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I. GENERAL PROVISIONS SECTION 1. This Act shall be known and may be cited as

This Act shall be known and may be cited as the Judiciary Appropriations Act of 2025. SECTION 2. Unless otherwise clear from the context, as used in this Act: "Means of Financing," or "MOF," means the source from which funds are appropriated, or authorized, as the case may be, to

are appropriated, or authorized, as the case may be, to be expended for the programs and projects specified in this Act. All appropriations are followed by letter symbols. The letter symbols, where used, shall have the following meanings: A General funds B Special funds C General obligation bond funds N

funds B Special funds C General obligation bond funds N Federal funds W Revolving funds "Position ceiling" means the maximum number of permanent or temporary positions authorized for a particular program during a specified period or periods, as noted by an asterisk or pound sign, respectively. an asterisk or pound sign, respectively. "Program ID" means the unique identifier for the specific program, and consists of the abbreviation for the judiciary (JUD) followed by a designated number for the program. PART II. PROGRAM APPROPRIATIONS SECTION 3. The following sums, or so much thereof as may be sufficient

following sums, or so much thereof as may be sufficient to accomplish the purposes and programs designated herein, are appropriated or authorized from the sources of funding specified to the judiciary for the fiscal biennium beginning July 1, 2025, and ending June 30, 2027. or the agency or government unit with the chief justice's approval, may enter into the undertaking with the federal government, private organization, or individual. SECTION 6. obligation bonds may be issued, as provided by law, to yield the amount that may be necessary to finance projects authorized in part II and listed in part IV of this Act; provided that the sum total of the general obligation bonds so issued shall not exceed $9,900,000. PART VI.

obligation bonds so issued shall not exceed $9,900,000. PART VI. SPECIAL PROVISIONS SECTION 9. part IV of this Act shall not lapse at the end of the fiscal year for which the appropriations are made; provided that all appropriations made for fiscal year 2025-2026 and fiscal year 2026-2027 that are unencumbered as of June 30, 2028, shall lapse as of that date. SECTION 10.

All unrequired balances in the general obligation bond fund, after the objectives of part II appropriations for capital improvements program purposes listed as projects in part IV of this Act have been met, shall be transferred to the judiciary project adjustment

been met, shall be transferred to the judiciary project adjustment fund. SECTION 12. If the amount allocated from the general obligation bond fund for a capital improvement project listed in part IV of this Act is insufficient, the chief justice may make supplemental allotments from the judiciary project adjustment fund;

may make supplemental allotments from the judiciary project adjustment fund; provided that supplemental allotments shall not be used to increase the scope of the project. SECTION 13. Where it has been determined that changed conditions, such as a reduction in the particular population being served, permit the reduction in the

the particular population being served, permit the reduction in the scope of a project listed in part IV of this Act, the chief justice may authorize such reduction of project scope. SECTION 14. The chief justice shall determine when and the manner in which the authorized capital improvement projects shall

the manner in which the authorized capital improvement projects shall be initiated. The chief justice shall notify the governor from time to time of the specific amounts required for the projects, and the governor shall provide for those amounts through the issuance of bonds authorized in part V of this

the issuance of bonds authorized in part V of this Act. SECTION 15. Any law or any provision of this Act to the contrary notwithstanding, the chief justice may supplement funds for any cost element for a capital improvement project authorized under this Act by transferring sums as may be

authorized under this Act by transferring sums as may be needed from the funds appropriated for other cost elements of the same project by this Act or by any other prior or future Act that has not lapsed; provided that the total expenditure of funds for all cost elements for

the total expenditure of funds for all cost elements for the project shall not exceed the total appropriation for that project. PART VII. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS AND EFFECTIVE DATE SECTION 16. If any portion of this Act or its application to any person or circumstances is held to be invalid for

any person or circumstances is held to be invalid for any reason, the remainder of this Act and any provision thereof shall not be affected. If any portion of a specific appropriation is held to be invalid for any reason, the remaining portion shall be independent of the invalid portion

the remaining portion shall be independent of the invalid portion and shall be expended to fulfill the objective and intent of the appropriation to the extent possible. SECTION 17. If any manifest clerical, typographical, or other mechanical error is found in this Act, the chief justice may correct the error.

in this Act, the chief justice may correct the error. All changes made pursuant to this section shall be reported to the legislature at its next regular session. SECTION 18. This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025. INTRODUCED BY: _____________________________ By Request Report Title: Judiciary Package; Appropriations; Budget

Effective 7/1/2025. The summary description of legislation appearing on this page is for informational purposes only and is not legislation or evidence of legislative intent.

overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

capital_expenditure_impact.prompt: Outline any expected capital expenditures related to the program or measure, such as investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure, based on capital budgets or agency plans. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note.prompt: If you are given a previous fiscal note. Please summarize the MAIN POINTS that are different from the previous fiscal note and the new fiscal note.

fte_positions.prompt: Detail any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions that have been added or modified in this version of the bill, including the number of positions, their roles, and any changes from previous versions. This should be around 3 sentences.

appropriations_changes.prompt: Identify and describe any appropriations that were previously unspecified or have been modified between versions of the bill, including the amounts and purposes of the appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
appropriations_changes.description: Changes to appropriations between bill versions

funding_sources_changes.prompt: Specify the method of funding (MOF) for appropriations and identify any changes in funding sources between versions, such as shifts between general fund and special fund appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
funding_sources_changes.description: Changes to funding sources and method of funding

department_impact.prompt: Describe any changes in which department is responsible for expending appropriations, including shifts from one department to another between bill versions (e.g., from Department of Health to Judiciary). This should be around 3 sentences.
department_impact.description: Changes in department responsibility for appropriations

reports_required.prompt: Identify any reports that agencies are required to submit to the legislature, including new reporting requirements or modifications to existing ones. This should be around 3 sentences.

pilot_program.prompt: If the bill creates a pilot program, describe the length of the pilot program and whether it was initially intended to be a pilot program or a permanent program. This should be around 3 sentences.

sunset_date.prompt: Identify the sunset date for the bill or program, including any modifications to the sunset date between versions. This should be around 2 sentences.

effective_date.prompt: Identify the effective date of the bill, noting if there was a defective effective date in a previous version and what the corrected effective date is. This should be around 2 sentences.
